[quote]Given that the lender has to pay for attorney and court costs, it's hard to imagine there will be any meaningful benefit to the lender, but that $20 would help someone making only $840 per month. Of course, this is the consequence of giving so much power to the lenders and so little recourse for the borrowers.[/quote]

The incentive is that lenders get to keep the loan on their balance sheet as an asset rather than a liability. IOW, the Potemkin Village banking system that operates in this country.
$20 a month for 20 years, on an $89,000 debt? I think that is very, very fair.

Excellent illustration of the absurdity of the system - Mr. Wallace has been ordered to pay $20 per month out of $840 income. That comes to $240 per year he will have to pay if the court simply keeps the order in place. Even if he lives another 40 years, the lender will get less than $10,000 back in today's dollars (which will certainly be worth less as adjustments are made for inflation). Given that the lender has to pay for attorney and court costs, it's hard to imagine there will be any meaningful benefit to the lender, but that $20 would help someone making only $840 per month. Of course, this is the consequence of giving so much power to the lenders and so little recourse for the borrowers. It's easier to walk away from a mortgage than a student loan. If the same rules applied to student loans, someone who walked away would incur a significant hit on their credit score which might inhibit their ability to get credit for a period of time. This would be a disincentive for people who are going to want to borrow to improve their standard of living. Considering that in many cases it now costs more for a college education than for a house, the whole system may collapse if there is no mechanism for relief. If enough people simply refuse to pay their debt, lenders will have to consider whether it's worth pursuing cases where net assets are so low that enforcing collection is nearly impossible. It's time for Congress to catch up with the reality of a debt crisis it has enabled.

Voting is important and emotional.  However, Mr. Romney should not use race to divide Americans.  He should not lie that Mr. Obama cut work requirement for Welfare when he actually strengthen the program.  Romney should not use birther talk to throw red meat at his base to divide Americans.  Mr. Romney should be better than Fox News and Rush Limbaugh, however, he's not, his whole campaign is based on lie and distortion rather than offer a clear policy to help Americans.  He's running on business experience, however, he's yet to release his business tax returns.  What's he hiding?

Sorry Dr. Williams, but we are entering the age of the Nocter. The reality is that information technology will allow PA's and NP's to provide 'good enough' care, often enough, that they will become accepted as 'providers'.

I see medicine as evolving from a medieval artisan-guild model to an industrial-corporate model. The key to economic viability will be adding value. If you're primary care that means backstopping a team of NPs or PAs. There will be disasters, and the inherent liability risk will mean that you will be forced into the arms of an ACO. Which will be fait acompli since the third party payers will refuse to deal with solo providers and small groups. The only escape will be to provide concierge care to the well heeled, or to become a high-end cash-only specialist.

People who can't pay cash are going to be relegated to being seen by non-physicians with long waits for specialists and surgeons. Once physicians become employees with salaries that are more or less dictated to them they will begin organizing and inevitably the focus will be working conditions. Unpaid call? Weekends? 16 hour days? Forget it. Clinical discretion will be circumscribed. That homeless guy in the ER, don't work him up too much or we might have to admit him, God forbid he ends up in the ICU.

This clock punching mentality will not only result in a physician shortage, it will undermine the culture of personal commitment to patients. And that will be the final tragedy.

Work hard and play by the rules and you will succeed and achieve the American dream. That’s a lie based on a logical fallacy: I am successful, which means that I am rich, (I suppose one could be a successful cheat) therefore I worked hard and played by the rules. “Play by the rules?” Rules for the rich where in an offshore IRA account with an investment of $80,000 becomes in excess of $100,000,000? There is no talk of a stacked decked for sons of wealthy fathers with Yale educations and Harvard law degrees.

There are successful teachers, scientists, contractors, government employees, etc., who just made a comfortable income. I practiced law for 40 years and worked long hours and played by the rules and was comfortable, no more and raised 2 sons. Today my sons in their 40's work harder than I ever did, are successful in what they do and are grossly underpaid for their work and talents and now they will have to work longer before retiring and will not have Medicare or Obamacare and perhaps no Social Security. It all depends on how many believe Ronmey’s lies.

Unfortunately, the way the system is structured it is actually better to pay the absolute minimum over the longest possible time, since at death the loan just goes away. For someone who has little prospect of paying the whole thing off, it would be better to pay as little as possible over the course of a lifetime rather than attempt to pay it off - there is really no incentive for paying it off other than getting rid of a monthly payment.

Community colleges used to be affordable. In the last twenty years, tuition has gone from less that $10 per unit to $30 per unit, and CC's are still the least expensive route to a four-year college education. Methinks you do not know the function of community colleges and the huge contributions they make to the education of middle- and low-income students.

BTW, there is no credit check for most private student loans, they are just given.

The main reason why all of us are not doctors, business owners, etc. is that the economy requires people to work for the doctors or business owners. Everyone cannot have a business with an employee or two any more than everyone can be above average. An army with only officers would be a joke.

Some of the people at the bottom may be sympathetic characters and some may be basically lazy or dishonest or irresponsible, with no excuses other than themselves for their lack of success. There should be a floor or safety net, and people should be encouraged to leave it as soon as they can.

I always love your columns, and I know they are oozing in sarcasm, but I can never resist weighing in from a serious perspective.

First, can we, once and for all, lay to rest the notion that this is a "free" economy? Our economy is so rigged in favor of the rich, wall street insiders, those who are connected, to name a few, that nobody who is not a member of these and other favored groups has a snowball's chance in hades of "succeeding" in the GOP's definition of success, with the exception of a few people, like Steve Jobs. These are people born on third base who act as if they hit a home run. Neither Romney nor Ryan nor any of the GOP phonies who claim to have "built it" succeeded on their own, and they certainly didn't succeed by the sheer dint of their hard work and the "free" economy.

Moreover, it tells us quite a bit about these two men and this party that none of them understands that many who depend on government programs have never had any opportunities, let alone the many they've had. Some were born drug addicted or developmentally disabled. Some have been abused throughout their lives, maybe even sexually abused. Some have been homeless or moved so often that their educational opportunities were limited or interrupted. There are myriad reasons why all of us are not doctors, lawyers, journalists, business owners. R&R's and the GOP's utter lack of compassion toward those less fortunate than they disqualifies them from holding any leadership role in government.

Actually, James Jordan, I suspect that the platform committee is the political convention version of the high school detention room. It's where they put the loudmouth unruly kids to keep them off the convention floor and away from the cameras and interviewers.
Sort of trying to limit the damage.
Historically, nobody remembers any of the "planks" in the "platform" minutes after the conventioneers disperse.
Some of the more single-issue-prone DO take note if their issue is NOT addressed (in the way they want) in the platform.

Ian: It is not right to compare physicians to "average" workers in that physicians have to pay for multiple years of complex training which in effect increases cost. They then have huge loans that the "average" worker does not have, which decreases "real" income. Since MD's in general literally are responsible for "life/death" issues ("average" employees are not) they have a higher level of responsibility, not to mention high malpractice insurance costs. Other developed countries subsidize medical education (it is often free) and malpractice suits are rare. These factors alone eat up earnings.

Whenever a statistic is given I always think about the "real" meaning of the statistic, not the topline number out of context.

I  know he's trying to do too much; he's trying to hit balls into the second deck even if he can't occasionally get one past second base.  Joba is surely trying - Just ask him.  Why, after yielding a few extrabase hits, he nearly finds a groove; too late, but, what the heck. "A" for effort. Thank you for that, Janet. I am not LDS but it has disturbed me that anyone who professes to the a Christian, let alone someone in a leadership position in the church community could be so careless and cynical with the truth.

It is not only a betrayal of his faith, it is a betrayal of himself.

Janet, how come we do not hear murmurs of disapproval from Mormons over Romney's growing reliance on Sheldon Adelson to finance his campaign? Isn't it troubling to LDS members that one of his principal supporters operates casinos? In Macau there are hints that his casinos are connected to prostitution as well. I keep waiting for this to become an issue in the LDS community, but so far it doesn't seem to be happening.

I have lived through many presidential campaigns. I watched the televised Kennedy - Nixon debate in 1960. Never have I been so animated against a candidate to the point of publicly denouncing him every opportunity I get than I am with Mitt Romney. This candidate, more than others, has made me angry and determined to see that he is not elected. It is personal.

We share a religious tradition. I know what he heard as a child when he attended Sunday School, the lessons he learned during seminary, and the talks he listened to while attending sacrament meetings. I know what he preached as a missionary. I know what he expected of the people in his ward and stake when he served first as their bishop and then as their stake president.

I know that as a child he memorized the 13th article of faith, which begins "We believe in being honest, true, chaste, benevolent, virtuous, and in doing good to all men." I know that as a stake president he interviewed hundreds of men and women for temple recommends and he asked each of them if they were honest in all their dealings with others. I know that he is yearly asked this question and must be answering "Yes."

Mr. Romney has profoundly betrayed a religious culture that I cherish by being the most dishonest presidential candidate I have ever known. There is no end that justifies his betrayal of his faith, of me and my family, and of the God he believes called him to save the nation. And, I can't let it go. It is personal.

Republicans exemplify the Scrooge attitude of reducing the surplus population.  Anyone who can not keep up  just does not deserve to be alive.  To them the purpose of life is 'success' however Republicans define that word, probably according to the amount of money you possess whether you were born with it or stole it makes no difference.  It used to be that only  males with the right skin color possessing land could vote.  Suposedly this made you a success.  Republicans have made every effort to restrict voting rights to only those who agree with them.  They would send us back to a time when voting and even the right to live was  severely restricted to plutocrats.  The rest of us should just die or go away.  To Republicans the basic dignity of life means nothing despite their endless lip service.

Unfortunately, the free-for-all scramble to the top is deeply imbedded in the American "Dream."

Why does an impoverished, downtrodden, underclass vote against their own best interests (not to mention better nature) to ensure that the best thugs accumulate the spoils? Because they believe that in a free-for-all society they have the best chance to become one of the best thugs. Civility and human decency don't enter into it, and why would one care about prosperity being widespread if it might reduce the chance of having more of it for oneself?

"... in a free economy, everybody will get what they deserve."

Republicans use this term, "free economy," as though they're talking about a fair economy ... a relatively level playing field. They're not.

What Republicans mean by "free economy" is "free-for-all economy." They have in mind a place where those with the strongest muscle, the largest forces on their behalf, the most money, and the most political influence batter and buy their way to the top.

The whole point of the American revolution was to throw off the yoke of the aristocratic idea of betters that justified the free-for-all economy and resulting diminished, deprived, harsh, often hopeless, way of life for everyone else.

That Romney, Ryan, Boehner, McConnell, Kochs, Adelson, and a host of others want to take this nation back to such an existence, want to undo the decades of fights, often with loss of life, for fairer opportunity to prosper, want to undo the hard-won, often with loss of life, rights for women and minorities ...their entire program is an attack on America, the history of American progress, and an attack on the vast majority of American citizens.

The American Dream is not about accumulating wealth by proving you're the best thug in a free-for-all. That's the mafia. The American Dream involves a civil society with widespread prosperity and human decency even among the vulnerable.

With all due respect Paul, I don't think your response is helpful. If you re-read the article, Mr. Wallace never stated that he was unemployable simply because he is blind. It seems to be a combination of factors, including diabetes, the fact that he lives in a rural setting without good public transportation, as well as the fact that he is legally blind. You should also note that the judge in his case pointed to expert testimony showing that being blind does not necessarily preclude one from working.

As disabled people, we already receive so much judgement from able-bodied individuals, that we really don't need to heap more on those in our own community. Everyone's situation is different, and just because you have been able to succeed in the workplace, does not mean that all blind or partially-sighted people can. We all have different levels of family support, racial and gender privilege, intellectual ability, financial means, community assets, and much more. Furthermore, sharing a single story of an individual success to illustrate the capabilities of an entire population, is never helpful as it is non-representative and subjective.

I'm sorry that you were offended by this article. I am always on the lookout for pieces that marginalize the disabled, and I honestly didn't see that here.

Thank you, Gail, for reading the Republican platform and dissecting parts of it for us.

That the Republicans would make continuing the sale of extra-bullet magazines a part of their platform is a stunning indictment of today's Republican Party and a sign (if we needed one) of the degeneration of a once serious political party.

And there is so much more to abhor in the platform (how about that abortion plank?) that it is hard to take it seriously, but, alas, we ignore it at our peril. If the Republicans were to be in the position to enact a significant percentage of their platform, they would set back the United States at least a hundred years.
I guess that is why some started calling him "lyin Ryan".

Please do not assign the vaulted concept of 'chutzpah' to someone like Paul Ryan. It is an insult to the chutzpah fraternity.
He is a pathetic and pathological liar, that's true, but he is no more likely to inhabit the world of chutzpahdom, then he is to order a bagel with a smear!

The falsehoods in Paul Ryan's convention address include the following:

1. Ryan blamed Obama for the closure of the GM plant in Janesville, Wisconsin. In fact, the plant closure was announced by GM almost 8 months before Obama became President.

2. Ryan blamed Obama for the failure of the Simpson-Bowles deficit commission and for not presenting a deficit reduction plan. In fact, Ryan voted against approval of the Simpson-Bowles report. Obama presented long-term deficit reduction plans in September 2010 and in Summer 2011; Congressional Republicans rejected these.

3. Ryan charged that Obama 'cut' $716 billion from Medicare. In fact, these are negotiated price reductions that *maintain* current benefits; Ryan included these savings in his own budget plan.

4. Ryan blamed Obama for the 2011 downgrade of US debt. In fact, Ryan led House Republicans in refusing a timely compromise on the U.S. debt ceiling and rejecting Obama's $4 trillion deficit reduction
proposal.

Lies and chutzpah.
